Hello Peter,

It is not completely clear for me what derivatives are you go=
ing to 
calculate. If the mixture  composition does not change, every 
ther=
modynamic function is a function of two parameters. Thus you can 
calculate=
 partial derivative over one parameter when other parameter 
is kept consta=
nt. For example, for the energy, partial derivative 
over temperature at co=
nstant volume is Cv. AFAIK calculating partial 
derivative of arbitrary the=
rmodynamic parameter is not (yet) 
implemented in Cantera. As a very simple=
 workaround I propose you to 
calculate in Cantera the energy as a function=
 of temperature at fixed 
pressure and other way round with a reasonable st=
ep and then use a 
spreadsheet or Matlab to calculate derivatives. Some fin=
e point is 
what type of derivatives do you want to calculate =96 frozen or=
 
equlibrium? If you want to calculate equilibrium derivatives, than 
you n=
eed to calculate equilibrium composition on every step, while 
when calcula=
ting "frozen" derivatives the composition should be kept 
constant ("frozen=
).
Hope that this helps.
Anatoli

erez" <plpd00@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
>

ting the derivatives of the

d to compute 
derivatives 
> respect to T and P for the internal energy, i.=
e., du/dT and du/dp. 
I 
> would appreciate any advice in this direction. I=
 am using the 
Cantera 
> toolbox in Matlab 7. Thank you very much for your=
 attention.

> Peter
